summary: This is an email from defense attorney Laura Menninger to Judge Nathan requesting an adjournment of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial and seeking to redact other clients' names from the motion, citing attorney-client confidentiality rules.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who sends the email requesting trial adjournment and redaction of other clients' names from court filings.

persons.name: Nathan
persons.context: US District Court judge presiding over the US v. Maxwell case, recipient of the adjournment request.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on the email regarding the trial adjournment request, likely part of the legal team.

persons.name: Bobbi Stemhenn
persons.context: Copied on the email regarding the trial adjournment request, likely part of the legal team.

persons.name: Nicole Simmons
persons.context: Copied on the email regarding the trial adjournment request, likely part of the legal team.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case US v. Maxwell, whose trial adjournment is being requested by her attorneys.

connections.description: Menninger is representing Maxwell in the criminal case and is requesting trial adjournment on her behalf.
Both are part of the legal team working on the Maxwell case, as evidenced by being copied on the same email.

events.title: Court Order Issued
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order (Dkt. 221) regarding the Maxwell case procedures.

events.title: Trial Adjournment Request
events.description: Defense attorneys for Ghislaine Maxwell file a letter motion requesting a 120 or 180-day adjournment of the trial.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team requested a 120 or 180-day adjournment of her trial in April 2021.
The defense cited attorney-client confidentiality rules (Rule of Professional Conduct 1.6) to request redaction of other clients' names from court filings.
The email references legal precedents from Indiana, Kansas, and Oklahoma supporting the confidentiality argument.
The document shows coordination between multiple defense attorneys (Menninger, Pagliuca, Stemhenn, Simmons) on the Maxwell case.
The defense indicated they would file either redacted or unredacted versions of the letter based on the court's direction.
